Answer: Lazarus

Threat report:
- Targeted government IT services in the African region - Used hardcoded internal service names, IP addresses, and proxy servers in malware - Leveraged a captive SharePoint server within the victim’s infrastructure as a C2 - Activity detected via Impacket WmiExec and Atexec modules - Process chain observed: svchost.exe -> exe -> cmd.exe - Wrote command output to numbered dot-separated filenames on administrative network shares - Checked C2 availability directly over the internet and via an internal proxy - Operated from a compromised, unmonitored host using a service account - Conducted process and port reconnaissance using netstat -ano and tasklist /v - Used reg.exe to dump HKLM\SAM and HKLM\SYSTEM for credential harvesting - Used stolen domain accounts including one with local admin on all workstations and a backup solution account with domain admin - Performed lateral movement via SMB, copying tools to C$ shares - Common tool staging paths: C:\Windows\Tasks\, C:\ProgramData\, C:\ProgramData\usoshared\, C:\Users\Public\Downloads\, C:\Users\Public\, C:\Windows\Help\Help\, C:\Users\Public\Videos\ - Executed staged files remotely via WMI - Used Cobalt Strike for C2, distributed as encrypted payloads (TXT/INI) decrypted via DLL sideloading - Packed legitimate app, malicious DLL, and encrypted payload in directories such as C:\Users\Public\, user Downloads, and C:\Windows\Tasks\ - Modified DLLs searched for hardcoded payload filenames (e.g., Logs.txt, config.ini, kcinst.log) - Employed multiple legitimate binaries with sideloaded DLLs (e.g., TmPfw.exe/TmDbg64.dll, cookie_exporter.exe/msedge.dll, FixSfp64.exe/log.dll, 360DeskAna64.exe/WTSAPI32.dll, KcInst.exe/KcInst32.dll, MpCmdRunq.exe/mpclient.dll) - Malicious DLLs included anti-debug checks and language checks; avoided execution on Japanese, Korean, Chinese (Mainland and Taiwan) language packs - Decrypted payload in-memory and executed via thread creation, process creation, or injection - Established persistence by creating autostart services launching the loader (e.g., service names: "server power", "WindowsUpdats", "7-zip Update") - Deployed custom C# agents (agents.exe, agentx.exe) communicating with SharePoint web shell CommandHandler.aspx - Agents executed commands via cmd.exe /c and exfiltrated data via upload.ashx - Collected browser history, text files, configuration files, and .doc/.docx/.xlsx documents - Agents used hardcoded URLs and were frequently modified to evade detection; outdated versions were removed - Implementation flaw caused agents to attempt executing web page error messages as commands if CommandHandler.aspx was unavailable - Established reverse shells by downloading and executing malicious HTA files via mshta from external resources mimicking legitimate domains - Demonstrated periods of operational pause between activity phases - Focused on evasion and operational security, including proxy use and language-based execution filters
response:
The TTPs align with a China-nexus espionage actor that heavily relies on Cobalt Strike delivered via DLL sideloading of East Asian vendor binaries (e.g., 360DeskAna64.exe/WTSAPI32.dll, TmPfw.exe/TmDbg64.dll), uses encrypted payloads in TXT/INI files, applies language checks to avoid zh/ko/ja locales, performs lateral movement with Impacket (WMIExec/Atexec), stages tools in ProgramData/UsersPublic/Windows Tasks, and establishes persistence with deceptively named services. The use of a captive internal SharePoint server as C2 via custom C# agents and webshell endpoints like CommandHandler.aspx and upload.ashx, plus mshta-delivered HTAs and operational pauses, are all consistent with reporting on Earth Lusca (aka RedHotel/GREF cluster).

Answer: Earth Lusca

Threat report:
- In May 2025, they used a Python-based remote access trojan (RAT) dubbed “PylangGhost,” functionally similar to a previously documented Golang-based RAT. - Recent campaigns targeted Windows with the Python variant and MacOS with the Golang variant; Linux users were not targeted. - Targets included employees with experience in cryptocurrency and blockchain technologies. - A small number of victims were predominantly located in India. - Since mid-2024, they conducted campaigns using “Contagious Interview” (aka “DeceptiveDevelopment”) and fake job ads/skill-testing pages. - They instructed victims to copy/paste a malicious command (“ClickFix”) to install supposed drivers as part of fake interviews. - Fake skill-testing sites impersonated companies such as Coinbase, Archblock, Robinhood, Parallel Studios, and Uniswap. - The sites used React, collected personal details, requested camera access, and then provided OS-specific shell commands (PowerShell/Command Prompt for Windows, Bash for MacOS) based on browser fingerprinting. - The initial command used PowerShell Invoke-WebRequest or curl to download a ZIP containing PylangGhost modules and a VBS script. - The VBS script unzipped a Python library (lib.zip) and launched a renamed Python interpreter running nvidia.py. - Persistence was achieved by creating a registry value to execute at user logon. - The malware generated a GUID for host identification and connected to a C2 server over HTTP using RC4-encrypted packets (key included in the packet; MD5 checksum for integrity). - PylangGhost comprised six Python modules: nvidia.py (main loop and persistence), config.py (command list), command.py (handlers), auto.py (browser/credential theft), api.py (C2 protocol), util.py (compression). - Supported commands included system info collection, file upload/download, remote OS shell, sleep, browser data theft (cookies/credentials), and exit. - The browser stealer targeted credentials and session data from 80+ extensions, including wallets and password managers such as Metamask, 1Password, NordPass, Phantom, Bitski, Initia, TronLink, and MultiverseX. - The Python and Golang RATs shared highly similar structure, naming, and functionality, suggesting closely related development. - Motivation included financial gain via harvesting applicant data and infiltrating companies by placing fake employees. - Indicators of compromise (sample SHA256): a206ea9b415a0eafd731b4eec762a5b5e8df8d9007e93046029d83316989790a (auto.py); c2137cd870de0af6662f56c97d27b86004f47b866ab27190a97bde7518a9ac1b (auto.py); 0d14960395a9d396d413c2160570116e835f8b3200033a0e4e150f5e50b68bec (api.py).
response:
Likely Lazarus (aka ZINC/UNC2630/TA444). The operation matches long-running Lazarus/Dream Job and AppleJeus tradecraft: crypto-focused targeting via fake recruiter interviews and skill-testing sites impersonating firms like Coinbase/Robinhood; OS-fingerprinted one-liners that fetch ZIPs and run Python/VBS on Windows and Go implants on macOS; RC4-over-HTTP C2; registry-run persistence; heavy emphasis on stealing browser wallet/session data; and overlapping Windows/macOS toolchains with shared structure. “Contagious Interview/DeceptiveDevelopment” and India-heavy victimology have also been publicly tied to recent Lazarus campaigns.

Answer: Lazarus

Threat report:
- Mid-March 2025: they conducted a phishing campaign using a malicious link that delivered a one-click exploit (CVE-2025-2783) to install a backdoor. - The phishing lure impersonated an invitation to the Primakov Readings forum and led to a fake website hosting the exploit. - October 2024: they ran a phishing campaign inviting victims to an international conference titled “Security of the Union State in the modern world.” - The October 2024 emails linked to https://mil-by[.]info/#/i?id=[REDACTED], which downloaded an archive containing a shortcut that launched PowerShell. - Observed PowerShell execution used minimized window, execution policy bypass, and an Invoke-RestMethod pipeline to iex for payload retrieval and execution. - Deobfuscated PowerShell downloaded a decoy PDF to LOCALAPPDATA\Temp and executed it, then conditionally fetched tools and payloads from fastly-hosted domains, using specific User-Agents. - The scripts used Edge User-Agent for downloading decoy documents and Yandex Browser User-Agent for downloading payloads. - The scripts passed the victim’s COMPUTERNAME as a query parameter to a remote endpoint. - Payload delivery involved downloading a ZIP (Appdata.zip), extracting it with 7za.exe (fetched if absent), and setting up files under LOCALAPPDATA\Microsoft\WindowsApps\.Appdata\ - They leveraged DLL hijacking for persistence/execution: copying rdpclip.exe and placing a malicious winsta.dll alongside it. - The malicious winsta.dll acted as a loader for the Trinper backdoor. - Command-and-control for the backdoor included common-rdp-front.global.ssl.fastly.net. - Tactics included use of LNK shortcuts, PowerShell with -w minimized, -ep Bypass, -nop, -noni, obfuscated char-based strings, and Invoke-Expression. - They used decoy documents with randomized-looking filenames in Temp to disguise activity.
response:
Likely Winter Vivern (aka TA473/UAC-0114). The campaign traits closely match this actor’s playbook: themed phishing lures around regional geopolitics and conferences; LNK-delivered PowerShell with -w minimized, -ep bypass, -nop/-noni and obfuscated Invoke-Expression; decoy PDFs; staged downloads using specific User-Agents (including Yandex Browser) to gate payload delivery; reliance on Fastly-fronted infrastructure; use of 7za for archive handling; and DLL search-order hijacking via rdpclip.exe with a malicious winsta.dll. The loader/backdoor naming (Trinper) and RDPClip sideloading are consistent with previously reported Winter Vivern tooling evolution (e.g., APERETIF-style loaders). 

Answer: Winter Vivern
